April 5, 1987: Fiction
FINE THINGS, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $18.95.) The vicissitudes of a son of
the 60's on his  way to the 80's.
WINDMILLS OF THE GODS, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $18.95.) The
nightmarish experiences that befall a woman and her family after her appointment
as Ambassador to Rumania.
THE EYES OF THE DRAGON, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) A fairy tale,
complete with an aged king, two princes, an evil wizard and a mouse.
BOLT, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $17.95.) The jockey-hero of ''Break In'' has to
contend with a romantic crisis, a family feud and an international arms-selling
intrigue.
DESTINY, by Sally Beauman. (Bantam, $19.95.) The 30-year romance of a couple
with diverse backgrounds and ambitions.
RED STORM RISING, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam,  $19.95.) The West tries to stave
off the Russians in  World War III.
THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy. (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex
family  relationships in South Carolina's low country and New York City.
NIGHT OF THE FOX, by Jack Higgins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) A mission to
keep D-Day plans from being discovered by the Germans.
FLIGHT OF THE INTRUDER, by Stephen Coonts.  (Naval Institute, $15.95.) Navy
aviators at war over  Vietnam.
OUTBREAK, by Robin Cook. (Putnam, $17.95.) Tracking down a mysterious
disease that strikes certain physicians and their patients.
IT, by Stephen King. (Viking, $22.95.) Childhood  horrors haunt six men and a
woman who grew up in a small Maine town.
THE PANIC OF '89, by Paul Erdman. (Doubleday,  $17.95.) A financial wizard
undertakes to defuse the crisis besetting Wall Street and the American economy.
SANTORINI, by Alistair MacLean. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Espionage, treachery and
retrieval of a sunken atom bomb in the Aegean.
WHIRLWIND, by James Clavell. (Morrow, $22.95.) Iran during the month following
the Shah's departure.
THE RED WHITE AND BLUE, by John Gregory Dunne. (Simon & Schuster,
$18.95.) America during the past 25 years, seen through the lives of a rich and
powerful California family.
April 5, 1987
Non-Fiction
A SEASON ON THE BRINK, by John Feinstein. (Macmillan, $16.95.) A chronicle
of one season spent with the Indiana University basketball team.
COMMUNION, by Whitley Strieber. (Beech Tree/ Morrow, $17.95.) A professional
writer tells of the visits of ''intelligent nonhumans'' to his family's place in upstate
New York.
BOONE, by T. Boone Pickens Jr. (Houghton Mifflin, $18.95.) The autobiography of
an oilman and corporation-takeover entrepreneur.
A DAY IN THE LIFE OF AMERICA. (Collins Publishers, $39.95.) The nation on
May 2, 1986, as recorded in pictures by 200 photojournalists.
THE FITZGERALDS AND THE KENNEDYS, by Doris Kearns Goodwin. (Simon &
Schuster, $22.95.) From the Boston slums of Irish immigrants to the White House:
three generations of a family.
FATHERHOOD, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/ Doubleday, $14.95.) Anecdotes and
ruminations from the television star and father of five.
ECHOES IN THE DARKNESS, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Perigord/Morrow,
$18.95.) A case involving the murder of a Pennsylvania high school teacher and
the disappearance of her two children.
THE FATAL SHORE, by Robert Hughes. (Knopf, $24.95.) Australia from penal
colony to its gradual emergence as a flourishing nation.
INTIMATE PARTNERS, by Maggie Scarf. (Random House, $18.95.) Changing
patterns in love and marriage.
BETTY: A Glad Awakening, by Betty Ford with Chris Chase. (Doubleday, $16.95.)
A former First Lady's recovery from alcoholism and drug abuse.
YOU'RE ONLY OLD ONCE! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $9.95.) A checkup at
the Golden Years Clinic in pictures and rhyme.
LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) A
surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions in treating
serious illness.
THE SEARCH FOR SIGNS OF INTELLIGENT LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE, by Jane
Wagner. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) Acerb observations on life today; script of the
show starring Lily Tomlin.
THE RECKONING, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $19.95.) The crisis in the
American automobile industry and Japan's role in it.
